message.content: We refer to PubMed Health for help. Vitiligo is a long-term skin condition in which patches of the skin lose their pigment. The course is usually slowly progressive and spontaneous repigmentation occurs in about 15% of patients. The disease is not relapsing and remitting, and keloid formation is not associated with it. Topical corticosteroids may be appropriate for patients with limited disease. Therefore, option (A) is the correct statement about this patient's suspected disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Vitiligo is a disorder characterized by patchy loss of skin pigmentation due to autoimmune destruction of melanocytes. The course of the disease is usually slowly progressive, and spontaneous repigmentation occurs in about 15% of patients. The disease is not relapsing and remitting with complete interval repigmentation, and keloid formation is not associated with regions of depigmentation. Topical corticosteroids are an appropriate treatment option.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation and leukocyte count suggest vitiligo. The typical course of vitiligo is slow progression with spontaneous repigmentation in about 15% of patients. The other options are either incorrect or not associated with the disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, option A is correct regarding the course of vitiligo, which is usually slowly progressive with spontaneous repigmentation in about 15% of patients. Option B is incorrect as there is no complete interval repigmentation. Option C is incorrect as there is no association between keloid formation and regions of depigmentation. Option D is incorrect as topical corticosteroids may be used for patients with limited disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Vitiligo is a disease characterized by hypopigmented patches and macules, and it usually progresses slowly, with spontaneous repigmentation in approximately 15% of patients. Keloid formation is not associated with regions of depigmentation and topical corticosteroids are appropriate for patients with limited disease. Therefore, the correct statement is that the course of vitiligo usually is slowly progressive with spontaneous repigmentation in 15% of patients.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Vitiligo is a slowly progressive disease that affects pigmentation, and spontaneous repigmentation occurs in 15-20% of patients. The disease is not relapsing and remitting, and keloid formation is not associated with it. Topical corticosteroids can be used for limited disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Vitiligo is a slowly progressive disease with spontaneous repigmentation in about 15% of patients. Relapsing and remitting disease course with complete interval repigmentation is characteristic of psoriasis. Keloid formation is not associated with regions of depigmentation. Topical corticosteroids are appropriate for patients with limited disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and physical examination suggest a diagnosis of vitiligo. Option (A) is correct as the course of vitiligo is usually slowly progressive with spontaneous repigmentation observed in around 15% of patients. Option (B) is incorrect as complete interval repigmentation is not seen in all patients. Option (C) is incorrect as keloid formation is not associated with regions of depigmentation in vitiligo. Option (D) is incorrect as topical corticosteroids are a first-line treatment option for localized vitiligo.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, only option A is correct. Vitiligo is a slowly progressive disease with spontaneous repigmentation occurring in 15% of patients. The disease is not relapsing and remitting, keloid formation is not associated with regions of depigmentation, and topical corticosteroids may be used for patients with limited disease.

We refer to the National Institute of Arthritis and Musculoskeletal and Skin Diseases for help. Vitiligo is a slowly progressive disease and spontaneous repigmentation may occur in 15% of patients. The disease is not relapsing and remitting, nor is keloid formation associated with regions of depigmentation. Topical corticosteroids are appropriate for patients with limited disease.
